The twin moons of Xylos, one the colour of bleached bone and the other a bruised violet, bled their spectral light through the polar-sheen of the balcony doors. Within the chamber, the air, scrubbed and recycled by systems groaning under the weight of centuries, tasted of ozone and sterile dust. Kaelen, heir to the Obsidian Throne and its crumbling hegemony, traced the faint, flickering star-charts projected onto the basalt slab of his desk. They were a lie of order in a galaxy of chaotic drift, a map of a territory his ancestors had conquered and his father was now losing, grain by crystalline grain.

A sound, dissonant and sharp, pierced the monotonous sigh of the climate regulators. It was a harmonic whine, thin as a nerve-fibre, a frequency that felt less heard and more directly imprinted upon the bones of his skull. He lifted his head, the holographic constellations swimming in his vision. The palace was an ancient, dying beast; its mechanical organs often produced such phantom noises—the death rattles of failing conduits and ossified circuitry. He dismissed it, his focus returning to the slow, majestic wheel of the Cygnus Rift.

There. Again. Closer.

This was no architectural groan. This was a sound with intention, a skittering, purposeful hum that vibrated with a predatory patience. Kaelen’s gaze swept the cavernous room, across the threadbare grandeur of tapestries depicting the First Reclamation, past the inert silver of the refreshment servitor, and into the deep, absolute shadows pooled in the alcove near the ceiling.

A mote of obsidian, no larger than his thumb, detached itself from the gloom.

It hung there, a metallic scarab birthed from the room’s deepest shadow, its single optic a pinprick of malevolent crimson. It was a hunter-seeker, a whisper-class model, proscribed by every treaty his dynasty had ever signed. Its design was an obscenity of miniaturization, a fusion of silent grav-plates and a core of focused energy. A weapon for assassins who valued subtlety over spectacle.

Time seemed to liquefy, stretching into a syrupy, slow torment. The political calculus of the attempt—which cousin, which disgruntled Guilder, which off-world power—flashed through his mind, a useless cascade of speculation. All that mattered was the physical reality of the thing. The red eye pulsed, scanning, locking onto his heat signature, the faint bio-electric field of his body. The whine sharpened, climbing the scale toward an unbearable pitch, the sound of a capacitor charging for a killing strike.

His hand, acting on some primal command that bypassed thought, swept the heavy folio from the desk—a tome of dynastic law—and hurled it. The drone sidestepped the tumbling book with an insectoid twitch, its movement a fluid violation of inertia. The air around it shimmered. A filament of incandescent light, thinner than a needle, lashed out, striking the basalt desk where his chest had been a second before. The stone glowed cherry-red for a heartbeat, a smell of superheated rock and vaporized silicon filling the air.

Kaelen was already moving, diving behind the immense, petrified-wood bedframe. Splinters of basalt, sharp as glass, rained down on the woven floor-mats. The drone circled, its hum a triumphant threnody. He was trapped. The chamber was a mausoleum of last resort, its doors sealed by chronometric locks until the morning cycle. The polar-sheen windows were rated to withstand micrometeorite impacts. Nothing could get in. Nothing could get out.

He pressed himself against the cool, ancient wood, his heart a frantic drum against his ribs. He could feel the drone’s search pattern, the methodical sweep of its sensors. It was not merely programmed; it was being guided. Somewhere, perhaps in this very palace, an operator was watching through that crimson eye, their thumb hovering over the firing stud. The thought was more chilling than the machine itself—the intimate, remote violation.

The whine grew louder, closer. It was coming over the bed.

A strange calm descended, the eye of a storm in his own mind. It was a feeling he sometimes touched in deep meditation, a resonance with the planet itself. The sand, the wind, the deep, geothermal pulse of Xylos. They said the first Atreides had been able to command the sandworms, that his bloodline carried the echo of the desert’s deep voice. For Kaelen, it had always been a myth, a mystical justification for their brutal rule.

Now, desperate, he reached for it.

He did not think, he *felt*. He felt the static charge in the recycled air, the faint magnetic field generated by the palace’s failing power core. He felt the ceaseless vibration of the world outside, the abrasive kiss of wind on stone. He pulled at these threads, not with his hands, but with the focus of his will, weaving them into a shield of incoherent noise. The star-charts on the desk flickered and died. The room’s ambient lighting sputtered, casting the scene in strobing relief.

The drone faltered. Its smooth glide became a stuttering, uncertain wobble. Its whine devolved into a frantic, agonized shriek as its delicate systems were flooded with chaotic energy. The red optic flickered erratically, lost in a storm of sensor ghosts. It was blind.

Kaelen launched himself from behind the bed. He grabbed the one object within reach that was not part of the palace’s integrated systems—a heavy, ceremonial crysknife, a relic of his initiation rites, resting on its magnetic plinth. The blade, milky and razor-sharp, was carved from the tooth of a great sandworm that had died in the deep desert before the first human ships arrived.

He did not throw it. He met the flailing drone in mid-air, a collision of ancient ritual and decaying technology. He swung the crysknife not as a blade, but as a club. The impact was a dull, unsatisfying crack of stressed metal and fractured crystal. The drone, its grav-plates failing, fell to the floor. It spasmed once, twice, a filament of energy discharging harmlessly into the thick pile of the rug, leaving a small, blackened scorch mark. Then, its crimson eye went dark.

Silence rushed back into the room, profound and suffocating. Kaelen stood panting, the crysknife heavy in his hand. The smell of ozone and burnt circuits was acrid in his throat. His temple throbbed where a piece of flying stone had grazed him. He looked down at the dead thing, a toy-like piece of malice, inert and pathetic.

Then he looked at his own hand, the one not holding the knife. A faint, coruscating pattern of blue energy, like heat-lightning trapped under the skin, danced across his knuckles before fading. The resonance remained, a low hum in his blood. The myth was not a myth. And in the silent, calculating dark of the palace, an enemy now knew he had survived. He was no longer just the heir. He was a threat.

TOPIC: An assassination attempt is made on the heir using a small, remote-controlled hunter-seeker drone in his bedroom. | VERSION: 7
--------------------
The twin suns of Aridian had bled a bruised violet into the horizon, leaving the Grand Spire of the Citadel to claw at a sky a-glitter with cold, indifferent stars. Within his chambers, high in that spire, Kaelen felt the planet’s latent heat radiate from the sand-fused stone walls. It was a constant, oppressive companion, a warmth that did not comfort but instead baked the moisture from one’s breath and rendered the air brittle. The recycled atmosphere from the Citadel’s failing life-support systems hummed a low, funereal dirge, a counterpoint to the keening of the ever-present wind scouring the armored glass of his window.

He was tracing the corroded filigree of a star-chart projector—a relic of a more optimistic age—when the anomaly first registered. It was not a sound, not at first, but a pressure change, a subtle warping of the room’s stale air. A dissonance in the ancient hum. Kaelen’s tutelage under the Dune-Mystics had taught him to listen beyond his ears, to feel the currents of the world as a blind man feels the sun. This was a current flowing the wrong way. A predator’s silence.

His gaze swept the chamber, a space of austere grandeur where decaying technology and priceless antiques waged a slow, losing war against the encroaching dust. A therm-tapestry depicting the First Convocation flickered, its woven light-fibers dying one by one. Nothing. He chided himself for the tremor in his hand, a weakness his father, the Archon, would have excoriated. An heir could not afford nerves; they were fissures into which assassins poured their poison.

Then he heard it. A note so high it was more a filament of pain in the auditory nerve, the sound of stressed crystal. It emanated from the shadows congregating beneath the sweep of his sleeping couch. From that pool of darkness, a thing of exquisite malevolence detached itself. It was no larger than his clenched fist, a shard of obsidian given venomous life. Its carapace was a mosaic of non-reflective polymers, its single optic lens a ruby droplet of focused hate. A hunter-seeker. Not a military model, brutish and loud, but a couturier’s weapon, elegant, silent, and utterly final.

Time seemed to granulate, each moment a coarse grain of sand falling through an unseen glass. Kaelen’s breath hitched, a traitorous sound in the sudden, predatory stillness. The drone lifted, its propulsion a whisper of displaced ions that stirred not a single mote of dust. It pirouetted with a nauseating grace, its ruby eye painting his form with an invisible targeting lattice. This was not the work of some back-alley syndicate. The precision, the sheer audacity of deploying it within the Archon’s Spire, spoke of a rival House, of high treason whispered in silk-draped halls.

His body, trained since birth for the precise violence of the ritual dueling circle, reacted before his mind could fully process the terror. He threw himself sideways, the heirloom decanter on a nearby table exploding into a thousand glittering arguments as he crashed through it. A heat-lance, needle-thin and incandescent, seared the air where his heart had been a microsecond before. The smell of ozone and super-heated stone filled the room.

The drone adjusted, its movements fluid and intelligent, a thinking weapon tethered to a remote butcher’s will. It was a hornet in his sanctuary, a violation that went deeper than the threat of mere death. It was a desecration of his bloodline’s holiest sanctum. Kaelen scrambled behind a heavy plinth supporting a bust of his grandfather. The drone circled, its hum a hypnotic threnody. It was learning the room, mapping his potential trajectories, its cold logic calculating the most efficient path to his annihilation.

Panic, a cold and greasy thing, tried to claw its way up his throat. He forced it down, drawing instead on the deeper catechisms of the desert. *The dune does not resist the wind; it yields and reforms.* He could not outrun the drone’s speed, nor could he withstand its weapon. He had to change the shape of the battle.

Peeking around the marble, he saw the ruby eye fix upon him. He feinted left, and as the lance of heat slagged the ancient stone, he lunged right, his hand closing around a heavy, ornamental weight from the desk—a geode from the Glass Sea, its heart a raw, uncut quartz cathedral. It was a piece of the planet, solid and real, a counter-argument to the drone’s sterile perfection.

The drone anticipated him, zipping with impossible velocity to cut off his retreat. It hovered before him, a jeweled hangman. In its polished carapace, Kaelen saw a distorted, terrified effigy of himself. For an instant, the world fell away, leaving only his reflection in the eye of his killer. And in that moment of profound stillness, he felt the planet’s deep song beneath his feet, the slow, grinding patience of rock and sand. He did not see the drone; he *felt* its intention as a dissonant chord in that song, a spike of murderous static. It was preparing for the final, pinpoint shot to the ocular nerve.

He did not throw the geode. He *became* the throw. His muscles, his bones, his desperation, all coalesced into a single, explosive act of will. The heavy crystal spun through the air, not at the drone itself, but at the space it would occupy in the next breath. His intuition, born of Aridian’s mystical dust, warred with the assassin’s cold technology.

For a heartbeat, the two hung in balance. Then the drone, in its flawless execution of a predicted flight path, moved directly into the path of the spinning rock.

The impact was not a crash but a wet, concussive pop, a sound of compressed technology and shattered crystal. The drone’s carapace fractured, spitting sparks and a plume of acrid, blue smoke. It fell, tumbling gracelessly to the floor, where its ruby eye flickered once, twice, and then went dark. A final, pathetic sizzle, and then a silence so absolute it felt like a vacuum.

Kaelen stood, chest heaving, the ghost of the heat-lance still tingling on his skin. The geode lay in pieces, its quartz heart scattered across the floor like fallen stars. On one of the larger, smoking fragments of the drone, he saw it—an almost invisible sigil etched into the polymer. The stylized, fractured diamond of the House of Shard.

His sanctuary was a ruin. The scent of ozone and betrayal hung thick in the air. The physical threat was neutralized, but the true attack had just begun. He walked to the window, the shards of the decanter crunching under his boot, and looked out upon the endless, shifting dune-sea. The real predators were not the machines they sent, but the men who held the controls, hidden somewhere in the perfumed, shadowed courts below. And in the deep quiet that followed the violence, he heard the desert, his desert, begin to answer.

Sleep, on Heliosyne, was a surrender not to darkness but to a lesser light. The binary glare of the twin suns, one a bloated amber giant, the other a searing white dwarf, seared the planet’s surface, and even through the polarized chromaglass of the aerie’s highest spire, the night was a bruised twilight of ochre and violet. Cassian, Heir-Designate to the Fading Throne of the Atreides… no, the House of Voron, lay suspended between waking and dreaming, his mind adrift on the planet’s deep, resonant hum—the Song of the Sands, as the mystics called it. It was a frequency to which his blood was attuned, a low thrumming that vibrated up through the bedrock of the palace, through the cooling metal of the floor plates, a lullaby of geological time.

Tonight, the Song was dissonant.

It was a subtle corruption at first, a single, sour note plucked on a wire of cosmic tension, a faint static that prickled the hairs on his arms. He came to full consciousness not with a gasp, but with a slow, cold certainty of intrusion. The air in his chambers, usually a sterile blend of recycled oxygen and sacred incense from the fungal caverns, carried a new scent: the acrid tang of ozone, the smell of a machine’s hot, meticulous thoughts.

His eyes, adjusted to the perpetual gloaming, scanned the vast, spartan room. The cantilevered bed, the single plinth of obsidian that served as a desk, the heavy tapestry depicting the First Landing—a masterpiece of woven thread turned brittle with age, its colours muted by centuries of unfiltered starlight. Nothing was amiss. Yet, the feeling persisted, a pressure against his senses, as if the very geometry of the room had been violated.

Then he saw it. A shard of polished night detaching itself from the deeper shadows of the vaulted ceiling.

It was no larger than his clenched fist, a composite of matte-black alloys and crystalline optics, shaped like a chitinous beetle. Its descent was utterly silent, a controlled fall cushioned by micro-gravitic repulsors whose whine was pitched just beyond the threshold of human hearing. Only the disturbance in the Song betrayed it. The drone—a hunter-seeker, an assassin-mote of exquisite lethality—pivoted in the stagnant air, its monocular lens a ruby droplet of pure, unblinking malevolence.

Time seemed to clot. Cassian’s breath caught, a dry knot in his throat. This was not the work of a common syndicate. The technology was old Dynasty, military-grade, forbidden. Its presence here, in the heart of the Citadel, was a political statement written in the language of imminent death. He thought of his father’s failing health, of the whispers in the court, of the hungry eyes of his uncle, Joric, whose ambition was a palpable force, a gravity that bent light and loyalty around him.

The seeker-drone locked onto his heat signature, a faint bloom of life against the chill of the synth-silk sheets. Its carapace split with a soft click, revealing the needle. A whisper of spun metal, finer than a nerve fiber, coated in a neurotoxin that would crystallize his synapses in a single, silent, ecstatic moment of agony.

He moved.

It was not a conscious decision but a primal, kinetic explosion. He hurled himself sideways, rolling off the far side of the bed as the drone scythed through the space his head had occupied a heartbeat before. The needle missed, striking the obsidian plinth with a sound like a single grain of sand striking glass. A network of fractal cracks, impossibly fine, radiated from the point of impact.

He landed hard on the flagstones, the impact jolting up his spine. The drone, its logic unimpeded by surprise, corrected its trajectory with an insectile twitch. The hum of its repulsors now dipped into the audible spectrum, a hornet’s threnody promising a swift, venomous end. Cassian scrambled behind the plinth, its cold, smooth surface a temporary shield. He could feel the thrum of the planet through the stone, a frantic, warning pulse that matched the frantic hammering of his own heart.

He had no weapon. The guards were two corridors away, behind pressure doors sealed for the night cycle. The room was a cage, and he was the prey. He risked a glance around the edge of the obsidian. The drone hovered, its red eye sweeping the room, processing, calculating angles of attack. It was patient. A machine could afford to be.

His gaze fell upon the ancient tapestry. Heavy, thick with the dust of ages, weighted at its base with a rod of corroded bronze. It was a shroud of history, a depiction of his ancestors’ folly and their triumph. Now, perhaps, a shroud for a machine.

The drone darted left, seeking to flank him. Cassian lunged. Not for a weapon, but for the tapestry’s release cord. He yanked it, the ancient mechanism groaning in protest. With a sound like tearing parchment, the vast tapestry tore free from its moorings. It fell not like cloth, but like a collapsing wall, a slow, inexorable wave of history and dead weight.

The drone, caught mid-maneuver, was engulfed.

For a moment, there was only the heavy *thump* as the tapestry and its bronze rod hit the floor, raising a cloud of ancient dust that glittered like powdered jewels in the dim light. Cassian held his breath, listening. A muffled, furious buzzing erupted from beneath the heavy fabric, the sound of a trapped, furious wasp. The tapestry twitched and bucked.

He knew it was not over. The machine would cut its way free. He needed to finish it. His eyes darted around, landing on the water carafe by his bed—a heavy, bulbous thing of hand-blown crystal, a relic from a time when water on Heliosyne was not a recycled commodity. He seized it, the cool, sweating glass a solid, reassuring weight.

He advanced on the thrashing tapestry, stalking the sound of the enraged machine. He raised the carafe high. A section of the fabric suddenly darkened as the drone’s energy blade, a sliver of pure heat, sliced through the ancient threads. The ruby eye appeared in the newly carved slit, searing and focused.

Cassian brought the carafe down with all the force of his desperation.

The crystal shattered against the drone’s casing with a percussive crash that was both musical and violent. Water exploded outwards. The drone convulsed as the liquid penetrated its delicate internal workings. Sparks erupted from its joints. Its ruby eye flickered, stuttered, and then went dark. The furious buzzing died, replaced by the faint, final crackle of shorting circuits.

Silence descended, a profound vacuum that sucked the air from his lungs. Cassian stood over the wreckage, chest heaving, the neck of the broken carafe still clutched in his hand. A single drop of his own blood, from a shard of embedded crystal, welled on his knuckle and fell, a dark tear on the ruined face of his ancestor in the tapestry.

The physical threat was over. But as he stared at the dead machine, a thing of forbidden artifice sent to his most private sanctuary, he understood. The message was not in the attempt itself, but in its intimacy. This was not a declaration of war. It was a whisper. A promise, etched in ozone and shattered crystal, delivered to the very heart of his fragile existence. He was the heir, but the throne was a distant shore, and a silent, venomous tide was rising.

The heat in the Tetrarch’s Spire was a physical presence, a pressure of baked silicate and stagnant air that Lyren had inhaled since birth. It clung to the woven histories of the tapestries, seeped into the crystalline data-slates, and settled as a fine, ochre film upon his skin. Outside the triple-paned armorglass, the twin suns of Xylos hammered the rust-colored wastes into a shimmering mirage. Inside, Lyren sought a different mirage, a cooler and more private desert within his own mind. He sat cross-legged on a worn meditation mat, his body a still point in the slow, inexorable decay of his chambers, listening. Not with his ears, but with the marrow of his bones, to the deep, resonant thrum of the planet itself—the Song of the Dust, his tutors had called it, the psychic hum of a trillion-trillion particles dreaming of mountains.

A dissonance intruded.

It was not a sound so much as a tear in the fabric of the room’s ambience. A high-frequency whine, thin as spun glass, that sliced through the planet’s thrumming bass note. Lyren’s eyes, the color of a bruised twilight sky, snapped open. The air, thick with the scent of hot metal and ozone from the straining enviro-unit, now carried a new, predatory charge. His gaze swept the gilded shadows of the room—the sand-scoured plasteel of his desk, the flickering hololith of his long-dead father, the alcove where his ceremonial robes hung like hollow men. Nothing. Yet the feeling persisted, a cold node of alien intent lodged in the familiar warmth of his sanctuary.

There. A flicker of motion near the ceiling’s ventilation grille, a place of perpetual shadow. It was no larger than his clenched fist, a shard of obsidian malice detaching itself from the darkness. Four delicate, articulated legs unfolded with silent precision, gripping the stuccoed ceiling. A single, multifaceted lens, ruby-red, pulsed with cold, analytical light. It was a Scarab-Seeker, a thing of chitin-and-wire artistry, its existence a whispered blasphemy in the halls of the Spire. Its rotors, currently still, were membranes of crystalline film, capable of a silence that defied physics.

Lyren did not move. To move was to confirm his living, breathing, thermal signature. His mind, a cartographer of this gilded cage, raced through geometries of escape and defense. The panic button beneath his desk was a lifetime away. The ornate letter opener, a sliver of sharpened jade, was an infantile defense against such a creation. He was a scholar, a listener to the planetary dirge, not a warrior. His body was a vessel for a dynasty, and the vessel was fragile.

The Scarab tilted its lens, a minute, insectoid gesture of appraisal. The ruby light swept across the room, bathing the antique furniture in a transient, bloody glow. It passed over the thermal signature of a still-warm cup of spiced tea, lingered on the heat-ghost of his body on the meditation mat, then settled, with chilling certainty, upon Lyren himself. A soft click, the sound of a firing mechanism engaging, echoed in the sudden, absolute silence. The whine returned, climbing the scale toward an unbearable shriek as the rotors began to stir the dusty air.

His breath hitched. The drone was a surgical instrument, designed for a single, silent purpose. It would launch a monomolecular filament, a whisper-thin thread that would sever nerve and bone before his brain could even register the pain. A clean, untraceable execution.

He had to break its logic.

Scrambling backward, Lyren flung a heavy, leather-bound tome from his nightstand. The ancient book on stellar cartography tumbled through the air, a pathetic, clumsy projectile. The Scarab, with a twitch of its rotors, dodged it effortlessly. The book struck the wall with a dull thud, its pages splaying like a broken wing. The drone’s logic remained unbroken, its focus absolute. It descended from the ceiling, a spider dropping on a thread of pure menace, its red eye an unwavering promise of annihilation.

Lyren fell back against the immense tapestry depicting the First Tetrarch’s ascension. The coarse, sand-pocked fabric scratched at his back. The drone closed the distance, the whine of its motors a dentist’s drill in his skull. The air grew cold before it, a pocket of displaced stillness. He could see the filament coiled in its firing aperture, a dark gleam of finality.

Closing his eyes, he abandoned the physical world. He let the chamber fall away, sinking past the fear, past the screaming of his own mortality, and plunged back into the deep, foundational music of Xylos. The Song of the Dust. It was always there, a current of immense, geologic patience. He had only ever listened. He had never tried to sing with it.

He found the drone's frequency, that needle of pure, vicious logic piercing the organic whole. It was an ugly, serrated thing, a frantic buzz of command-and-control signals from some distant, unknown puppeteer. He did not fight it. He *enfolded* it. He gathered the planet’s deep hum, the resonant frequency of the very dust motes in the air, the vibration of the bedrock miles beneath him, and focused it. He began to hum, a low, guttural tone that was not his own voice but an echo of the planet’s.

The Scarab faltered. Its descent stuttered, its rotors beating erratically against a pressure that wasn’t there. The ruby eye flickered, a confusion of conflicting inputs. The remote signal screamed *kill*, but the very air around it, vibrating with a power ancient and vast, whispered *sleep*. The two imperatives warred within its delicate crystalline mind.

Lyren pushed harder, pouring his will into the sound, shaping the Song into a shield, then a weapon. He felt a trickle of blood from his nose, the cost of such an exertion.

The drone began to convulse. It spasmed in the air, its articulated legs twitching, its body corkscrewing violently. A wisp of blue smoke curled from its carapace. The high-pitched whine fractured into a discordant shriek of tortured metal and overloaded circuitry. With a final, explosive pop, the ruby lens shattered. The Scarab-Seeker, its strings cut, dropped to the stone floor with the inert clatter of dead metal.

The silence that descended was not peace; it was a vacuum, ringing with the ghost of the drone’s cry and the planet’s deep, satisfied thrum. Lyren slid down the tapestry, his limbs trembling, his breath coming in ragged gasps. Dust motes, once agitated, settled in the beams of light slanting from the window, a silent, falling snow of red sand.

He stared at the broken thing on his floor, a constellation of shattered carapace and fused wire. The assassination attempt was over. The political statement, however, had just been made. He pushed himself to his feet, wiping the blood from his lip with the back of a shaking hand, his twilight eyes cold and hard.

Ninth. This had been the ninth attempt. And the first he had survived entirely on his own.

TOPIC: An assassination attempt is made on the heir using a small, remote-controlled hunter-seeker drone in his bedroom. | VERSION: 10

The heat of Xylos never truly surrendered to the night. It retreated into the planet’s core, a slumbering beast whose breath still warmed the sandstone arteries of the Tetrarch’s spire. In his chambers, Kaelen felt it as a pressure behind the eyes, a persistent weight upon the manufactured cool issuing from the groaning atmospheric condensers. Sleep, on this world, was not a surrender but a tactical retreat, a brief cessation of hostilities with an environment that despised soft flesh.

Tonight, the retreat was failing. Kaelen lay suspended in the liminal state between wakefulness and dream, his senses attuned to the palace’s ancient metabolism: the ceaseless hum of life support, the distant, percussive clang of a servitor-warden on its patrol, the whisper of sand-heavy wind against the armored glass of his balcony. Yet beneath these familiar layers of sound, a new note had inserted itself. It was a dissonant chord in the Song of Xylos, that resonant frequency in his blood that spoke of planetary truth, of deep time and deeper thirst. This new sound was a whine, thin and sharp as a nerve filament, an insectile keen that scraped against the quiet.

He opened his eyes. The twin moons, Phos and Deimos, cast a spectral, bifurcated light across the chamber, carving long, funereal shadows from the hulking, heirloom furniture. A holographic star-chart shimmered near the ceiling, its nebulae rendered in dying-ember reds and cold-fission blues—a relic of a more opulent age, now prone to flickering like a faulty memory.

There. A flicker that was not memory.

Against the star-chart’s glow, a mote of darkness detached itself, a sliver of nothingness that resolved into a shape. It was no larger than his fist, a composite of matte-black polymers and crystalline optics, a wasp of spun glass and malice. It hovered for a pregnant second, its movements too fluid, too silent for any natural creature. Its logic was the cold, clean geometry of murder. A hunter-seeker.

The breath caught in Kaelen’s throat, a knot of ice in the furnace of his chest. This was not the clumsy brutality of a hired blade or the unsubtle devastation of a shaped charge. This was a statement. An artist’s signature written in poison. The Technocrat Guild, he thought, the thought itself a shard of glass. Only they possessed the craft for such an exquisite instrument of death, and only they stood to gain so much from a clean, deniable severing of the dynastic line.

The drone vectored, its movements frictionless, its hum dropping an octave into a predatory thrum. It swept the room in a lattice of unseen light, mapping, analyzing, identifying the thermal bloom of a living heart. His heart.

Kaelen moved. Not with a shout or a panicked scramble, but with a fluid roll taught to him by tutors who believed the body’s first duty was to cheat gravity. He fell from the embroidered silks of his bed to the cold flagstones behind it, the motion a single, desperate exhalation. The air where his head had been hissed, ionized. A scent like ozone and scorched linen filled the space he had just vacated. He heard the faint *tink* of a micro-dart embedding itself in the dense, petrified wood of the headboard. A neurotoxin, likely. Swift. Silent. Elegant.

He pressed his back to the bed’s massive base, the rasp of his own breath a roar in his ears. The drone’s hum was closer now, a persistent, inquisitive sound. It circled the bed, a patient predator. Peering through the gap between the frame and the floor, he saw its single, ruby-red optical sensor pulsing, a baleful cyclopean eye. It knew he was here. It was merely calculating the most efficient trajectory for the kill.

His chamber, once a sanctuary, had become a cage of their shared design. The sandstone walls, thick enough to repel orbital bombardment, were now just surfaces for a ricochet. The heavy, brocaded tapestries depicting the Ascendancy of the First Tetrarch offered concealment, but no real cover. His mind raced, a frantic abacus clicking through impossible odds. No weapon. The guards were two corridors away, beyond reinforced doors designed to prevent intrusion from without, not to allow escape from within.

The drone rose, hovering over the bed, its sensor canted downwards. It was preparing to saturate the area, to punch a volley of darts through the mattress.

An idea, born of desperation and the desert’s brutal pragmatism, sparked in Kaelen’s mind. The balcony. Its doors were thick, yes, but they were a mechanism, a machine. And all machines, especially the ancient, decaying technologies of Aethelburg, had their flaws.

He pushed off the floor, a blur of motion. He did not run from the drone but towards its anticipated path, angling for the balcony. The drone, its calculations momentarily disrupted by his unexpected vector, swiveled. Its whine climbed to a piercing shriek as it accelerated. He felt a phantom heat trace a line across his shoulder as a dart carved the air beside him.

He slammed his palm against the activation rune for the balcony doors. The ancient mechanism groaned in protest, a sound of grinding gears and tortured metal. For a terrible, elongated moment, nothing happened. The drone closed the distance, its stinger—a fine, needle-like appendage—extending from its chassis with a soft, lubricated click.

Then, with a shudder that shook the very walls, the immense slab of armored glass and steel began to retract into the ceiling.

Kaelen did not wait. He threw himself through the nascent opening, tumbling onto the wind-scoured stone of the balcony. The air outside was a physical blow—sand-sharp and searingly dry. Below, the city sprawled, a grid of weary lights drowning in a vast, black ocean of desert.

The drone followed, a shard of obsidian given malevolent life, silhouetted against the bloated moons. Here, in the open, it was faster. Unconstrained. It feinted left, then darted right with impossible speed. Kaelen scrambled backward, his bare feet skidding on the stone. He was at the balustrade, the vertiginous drop behind him a final, lethal answer.

He risked a glance back at the door mechanism. The massive panel was still retracting, its counterbalance—a colossal weight of quarried iron—descending slowly within the wall cavity, its position marked by a greased and glittering chain.

The drone came for him. No more feints, no more calculations. This was the final, direct strike. Its ruby eye was a pinpoint of focused hate.

Kaelen waited, his entire being compressed into that single, ticking moment. He watched not the drone, but the shadow it cast upon the stone. When the shadow was nearly upon him, he dropped, throwing his body sideways, flush against the balustrade.

As the drone shot through the space he had occupied, he reached up, his fingers finding the thick, greasy links of the counterbalance chain. With a roar dredged up from his very soul, he heaved. His muscles screamed, but the chain moved, its inertia overcome.

The drone, its programming unable to account for the sudden introduction of a multi-ton variable, was caught. The descending counterbalance slammed into the delicate machine, not with a crash, but with a sickening, final *crunch*. There was a brief, incandescent flash of overloaded circuitry, a puff of acrid smoke, and then silence. The shattered remnants of the guild’s elegant message clattered onto the balcony, no more threatening than a handful of pebbles.

Kaelen lay panting, his cheek pressed to the cold stone. The chain had torn the flesh from his palms. A dull fire bloomed in his shoulder where a fragment of the drone’s casing had struck him. But he was alive.

He pushed himself up, leaning on the balustrade, and looked down at the broken thing. It was just scrap now, its malevolence extinguished. But it had been more than a weapon. It was a word in a conversation, an un-sheathed stinger revealing the true nature of the peace his father had so carefully curated. The war was not coming. It was here, in his room, in the blood welling in his hands. And the long, hot night of Xylos had only just begun.

TOPIC: A dinner party where the new rulers try to navigate the complex politics and etiquette of the planet's elite class. | VERSION: 1

**Chapter 7: The Sanguine Draught**

The air in the Matriarch’s Refectory was a lie, a cool, placid fiction held against the kiln-blast of the Xylan wastes by groaning atmospheric generators. Kaelen felt the planet’s true breath, a dry and insidious heat, pressing against the crystalline walls, searching for fissures in the decaying technology that sustained this final bastion of the old elite. Sweat, an unwelcome and alien moisture on this dessicated world, traced a cold path down his spine, trapped beneath the stiff, off-world fabric of his commander’s tunic. His was the uniform of a conqueror, yet here, in this cavernous chamber carved from the planet’s core-stone, he felt like a specimen pinned for observation.

Across the obsidian table, polished to a depth that seemed to swallow the light from the flickering holo-sconces, sat the Scions. They were remnants, ossified relics of a dynasty his fleet had shattered in a single orbital barrage, yet their power lingered, an atmospheric poison he had yet to analyze. Their leader, Matriarch Oryna, presided from a throne-like chair of petrified Xylan bone. Her face was a mask of serene wrinkles, a topographical map of centuries, and her eyes, dark and unblinking, held the placid cruelty of a desert predator that knows its prey has nowhere left to run.

The meal had been a sequence of silent challenges. Translucent jellies that quivered with captured bioluminescence, served on plates of wafer-thin, resonant metal; strips of cured sand-serpent, so salted they scoured the palate; crystalline fungi that crunched like glass and tasted of ozone and dust. Each course was a test of his fortitude, his adaptability. Lyra, seated to his left, her own discomfort masked by a predator’s stillness, had met each challenge with a slow, deliberate grace, a silent counterpoint to his own rigid control. Her presence was an anchor in this sea of veiled hostility.

“Our world is… austere, Commander Kaelen,” Matriarch Oryna’s voice finally materialized in the oppressive silence. It was not a sound of air passing over vocal cords, but of fine sand abrading ancient stone. “It demands resilience. It rewards only that which can endure.”

Her gesture, a languid wave of a hand veined like a dried leaf, summoned a serving drone. The machine, an elegant but sputtering antique, hummed unevenly as it drifted forward, its anti-grav emitters whining a discordant note. It bore a single decanter of deep, sanguine fluid and two thimble-sized crystal cups.

“Generations of my line have perfected the art of endurance,” she continued, her gaze never leaving his. “We do not drink water for pleasure. Water is life, function, a currency more precious than the heavy metals in your starship’s hull. For communion, for ceremony… we have this.”

The drone placed the cups with an unnervingly precise click, one before him, one before Lyra. The Matriarch ignored Lyra completely, her focus a palpable weight on Kaelen alone. The liquid in the decanter did not slosh; it seemed to fold in upon itself, a viscous, living crimson that caught the dying light in its depths.

“It is the Tears of Xylos. Harvested from the deep-strata mycelia, which drink from aquifers untouched by the scouring suns for millennia. Each drop is a memory of the deep, quiet earth. To drink it is to accept the soul of this world into your own.” The unspoken addendum hung in the air, heavy and suffocating: *And to refuse is to declare yourself forever alien, forever an enemy.*

Kaelen’s throat was a desert in itself. This was the true test, the one the strange foods had merely foreshadowed. His mind, a tactical engine, raced through probabilities. A poison, swift or slow? A psychotropic agent designed to shatter his will, to make him pliant? Or was it merely what she claimed—a ritual, a piece of political theater designed to force a gesture of submission? He felt Lyra’s leg press infinitesimally against his own, a silent, urgent warning. *Caution.*

He looked into the cup. The crimson fluid seemed to throb with a faint, internal light, the colour of a fresh wound. He could smell it now, a scent that was not a scent, more a presence in the back of his throat—of cold stone, of ancient, undisturbed salt, of something metallic and organic intertwined. The generators hummed their failing threnody. The dust motes, eternal companions in every Xylan interior, danced in the holographic light, tiny ghosts witnessing his choice.

To refuse was simple. It was the act of a conqueror, a clear demarcation of power. *I am not of you. I rule you.* But it would also galvanize the Scions, confirming their fears and solidifying their covert resistance. He needed their compliance, the seamless transfer of administrative control their ancient networks provided. He could not rule a planet of ghosts and martyrs.

To accept… to drink… was to walk into their world, onto their terms. It was a concession, a sign that the new power was willing to bend to the old ways. It was a risk his body screamed at him not to take. His own biology, calibrated for the verdant, high-gravity world of his birth, already struggled against Xylos’s thin, abrasive atmosphere. What would this alien distillate do to his system?

His gaze met Oryna’s. Her expression was one of absolute patience. She had set the board, made her move, and would wait an eternity for his response. It was the patience of rock, of a world that measured time in geological epochs, not in the frantic heartbeats of a short-lived off-worlder.

With a slow, deliberate movement that cost him a universe of will, Kaelen reached for the cup. The crystal was cold, a shocking contrast to the ambient warmth. He lifted it. The sanguine liquid clung to the sides, its viscosity unnatural. He saw his own distorted reflection in its dark surface—a pale, drawn face, a stranger in a strange land, about to consume its very essence.

He held the Matriarch’s gaze, a final, silent declaration. *This is not submission. This is consumption. I will take your world, your traditions, your memories, and I will make them my own. I will make them my tools.*

He brought the cup to his lips. The cold was the first shock, a profound, mineral cold that felt like swallowing a piece of the planet’s deep crust. Then the taste flooded him—not a flavour, but a cascade of sensory data. It was the taste of iron and salt, of utter darkness, of the immense, crushing weight of rock and time. A ghost of a sensation, an echo of a thought not his own, flickered at the edge of his consciousness: a vision of endless, silent caverns, of water seeping through stone for a million years, of a slow, blind, fungal consciousness spreading in the dark.

He swallowed. The liquid descended, a cold stone into the pit of his stomach.

Across the table, for the first time, the faintest ghost of a smile touched Matriarch Oryna’s lips. It was not a smile of welcome. It was a smile of ownership. He had drunk the Tears of Xylos. He had passed her test. And now, a part of this dying, venomous world was inside him forever. The room felt colder, the silence deeper, and the victory he had won in the cold vacuum of space felt suddenly, terrifyingly, insignificant.

TOPIC: A dinner party where the new rulers try to navigate the complex politics and etiquette of the planet's elite class. | VERSION: 2
--------------------
The heat was a physical presence, a shroud woven from silica and sun, pressing against the grand salon’s failing atmospheric shields. Through the armored glass, the twin moons of Xylos bled a bruised, violet light onto dunes that had swallowed civilizations. Inside, the air, thick with the scent of spun-sugar fungi and scorched ozone, clung to Kaelen’s skin like a fever-dream. The formal high-collar of her new Commander’s uniform, a garment meant to project authority, felt instead like a garrote slowly tightening with each shallow breath.

She sat at the head of a table carved from a single petrified leviathan bone, its polished surface reflecting the flickering holographic sky above. Constellations long dead wheeled in a ghost-dance across the ceiling, a testament to the Suren dynasty’s decaying grandeur. Her co-ruler, Rhys, sat opposite, his face a mask of serene diplomacy that Kaelen knew was as much a fabrication as the cerulean heavens above them. His fingers, long and elegant, rested near a crystalline goblet, a study in calm she could not hope to emulate. Her own hands were clenched beneath the table, knuckles white, the memory of a blaster’s grip an aching ghost in her palm.

Their host, Matriarch Valeriana of House Suren, presided from the table’s center. She was a creature of immense age, her skin a parchment of fine lines, her eyes—the color of rust and shrewdness—missing nothing. Valeriana and the other Great House scions arrayed around the table were the planet’s true sinews and bones. Kaelen and Rhys had merely shattered the spine in their swift, brutal campaign. This dinner was the first, delicate attempt to set the new one.

“The Aquifer’s Lament,” Valeriana intoned, her voice a dry rustle of sand-swept silk, as servants placed delicate, steaming bowls before them. “A broth rendered from the deep-strata molds. A reminder that even in the darkest, most crushing depths, life persists.”

The words were a stone cast into the placid surface of the conversation, its ripples pure political theater. A reminder of who controlled the deep aquifers, the lifeblood of this desiccated world. Kaelen watched Rhys incline his head, a perfect gesture of appreciative understanding. She forced her own muscles to mimic the motion, the effort immense. She was a soldier, a strategist. She understood the calculus of orbital bombardment, the logistics of a planetary siege. She did not understand a language where soup was a threat.

The broth tasted of damp earth and something metallic, a flavor that spoke of immense pressure and ancient minerals. It was not unpleasant, merely alien, coating her tongue in a film of ancient secrets. She ate, concentrating on the precise, silent motions of the others’ utensils, her every movement a betrayal of her origins—a child of the orbital foundries, raised in the clangor of recycled metal and the stark functionality of zero-gravity.

“Your campaign was… efficient, Commander,” said a man to her left, Lord Jaxom, his face a jowly ruin held together by expensive gene-therapies. The word ‘efficient’ was left to hang in the air, freighted with the ghosts of his private armies, now so much vaporized scrap in the Scouring Wastes.

“War demands efficiency, my Lord,” Kaelen replied, her voice flatter, harsher than she intended. “Waste is a luxury the victor cannot afford, and the vanquished cannot reclaim.”

A brittle silence descended. Rhys shot her a look, not of admonishment, but of caution—a subtle narrowing of his eyes that screamed *parry, don’t thrust*.

Valeriana’s lips curved into a smile that did not touch her reptilian eyes. “A stark philosophy. But then, you were not raised on the Litany of the Sands.”

The mystical cant began there. This was the true test, the part Rhys had drilled into her for days. The culture of Xylos’s elite was interwoven with a complex, quasi-religious system of etiquette tied to the planet’s ecology. The Litany was its core text, a series of aphorisms and parables about survival, patience, and the sacredness of water.

As if on cue, the main course was cleared and the ritual began.

Servants, moving with a silent, synchronized grace, placed a series of five small, crystalline vials before each guest, each containing a thimbleful of clear liquid. The Water-Tasting. The ultimate expression of power and reverence on Xylos.

Valeriana raised the first vial, holding it to the bruised moonlight. “From the high-altitude condensers of Mount Keres. The Ephemeral Draught.”

Kaelen’s heart hammered against her ribs. *Ephemeral first, Rhys had said. Sip, don’t drink. Acknowledge the sky’s fleeting gift.* She watched the others, her gaze sweeping the table, cataloging the minute rituals. The slight bow of the head, the way they held the vial with two fingers and a thumb, the meditative pause before tasting. She copied them, the cool, sterile taste of atmospheric water a phantom on her tongue.

The second was the Recycled Flow, water from the city’s closed-loop system. It was served a degree warmer, its taste faintly organic. The ritual here was to swirl it, a gesture acknowledging the cyclical nature of life. Kaelen’s hand trembled, the motion feeling clumsy, sacrilegious. The air grew thick with unspoken judgment.

Third, the Deep Aquifer’s Bounty, cold and heavy with minerals. The elixir of the old houses. This was to be held, its chill allowed to seep into the fingertips, a communion with the planet’s deep, hoarded wealth.

Fourth, the Polar Melt, a rare and decadent import from the planet’s tiny, dwindling ice caps, reserved for the most sacred occasions. It was tasted with eyes closed.

Then came the fifth vial. The Salt-Gift. Brine from the deepest desalination wells, barely potable, a symbol of suffering, of the struggle against the inevitable heat-death of their world. The Litany dictated this was to be touched to the lips, but not drunk. A gesture of humility. A recognition of the poison that encircled their fragile existence.

Kaelen felt Valeriana’s gaze upon her, a physical weight. Here was the fulcrum. Here, her legitimacy would be weighed. She saw the minute, anticipatory smirks on the faces of the other lords. They expected the off-worlder, the brutal conqueror, to fail this test of nuance. To balk at the brine, or worse, to drink it, revealing her ignorance.

She raised the fifth vial. The acrid, salty scent filled her nostrils. She saw, in her mind’s eye, the faces of her soldiers, their lips cracked and bleeding in the final push across the Salt Flats. She remembered the desperation of the city’s poor, huddled around malfunctioning public water dispensers. This suffering was not a symbol to her. It was a memory etched in sweat and blood.

In a single, fluid motion that broke utterly with the rigid ceremony, she brought the vial to her lips and drained it.

A collective, sharp intake of breath hissed around the table. Lord Jaxom flinched as if struck. Rhys went perfectly still, his diplomatic facade for the first time cracking to reveal the strategist beneath, calculating the fallout of her cataclysmic breach of etiquette.

Kaelen placed the empty vial down with a soft, deliberate click that echoed in the cavernous silence. She met Valeriana’s gaze, her own eyes burning with the salt’s sting and a cold, hard fire.

“We did not come here to taste suffering, Matriarch,” Kaelen said, her voice low and steady, each word a precisely placed explosive charge. “We came to end it. From this day forward, all water is for all people. That is our litany.”

The silence that followed was no longer merely oppressive. It was absolute, the sound of a world holding its breath, waiting to see whether the old bones would bow, or if they would finally, irrevocably, break.

The heat was a physical presence in the bio-lumened conservatory, a wet, clinging shroud that smelled of mineral dust and blooming night-fever orchids. It pressed upon Kaelen’s skin, a constant reminder of his otherness, of the blood in his veins that had not been thinned and tempered by generations on this kiln of a world. He, whose victories had been carved with plasma and iron across the blasted continents, felt the unfamiliar constriction of the high, stiff collar, a silken garrote tightening with every subtle shift of the old woman’s gaze.

Across the obsidian table, polished to a depth that seemed to swallow the light, Lady Elara of House Vorne presided. She was a creature of desiccated antiquity, her breath a faint hiss from the silver rebreather filigreed to her throat. Her body, frail as a dried leaf, was merely a scaffold for the immense, unyielding weight of her will. The failing cyb-neural lace at her temple pulsed with a wan, turquoise light, a dying star mirroring the decaying technology that held her ancient estate together against the ravenous ochre sands. Her guests, the scions of the other Great Houses, were arrayed like statues in a forgotten tomb, their faces impassive masks of civility, their jeweled hands resting near utensils forged for rituals Kaelen could not begin to comprehend.

A low-frequency hum emanated from the conservatory’s atmospheric regulators, a sound like a distant mourning. Outside the triple-paned, radiation-shielded glass, the twin, merciless suns of Xylos were setting, casting the dunes in bruised shades of violet and blood-orange. This dinner was not a celebration of his new order; it was an assessment, an autopsy of the power he thought he had won.

A servitor-drone, its chrome casing scuffed with age, drifted silently to Kaelen’s side. It extended a crystalline vessel containing a clear, shimmering liquid. Water. Here, on a planet where moisture was mined from deep-earth aquifers and meted out with the reverence of sacrament, this was the first test. He remembered the briefing from his strategos: *Do not drink. Await the host’s gesture. It is a sign of trust, of submission to their customs.*

He kept his hands clasped in his lap, the muscles in his forearms bunching into hard knots. The drone hovered, its optical sensor a single red dot trained upon him. The silence in the room deepened, stretching until it became a tangible force, a pressure against his eardrums. Lady Elara watched him, her eyes, clouded with age and technological enhancement, holding a dispassionate, reptilian curiosity. She was waiting for him to fail, to reveal himself as the barbarian they believed him to be.

Finally, with a movement so slight it was almost imperceptible, she inclined her head. A collective, silent exhalation seemed to pass through the room. Kaelen reached for the vessel, his fingers brushing the cool, impossibly smooth crystal. He brought it to his lips, the scent of ozone and purified minerals rising to meet him. He took a sip, the water a shock of cold purity in his parched throat. He had passed. He had not submitted, but he had acknowledged their game.

The first course arrived. Glistening, iridescent slabs of what his briefing had identified as Shale-Crab, served on frozen platters that wept delicate veils of condensation into the oppressive heat. Its alien scent, a mix of brine and something metallic, coiled in the air. The accompanying utensil was a fork with three tines, two of which were hinged and articulated, controlled by a pressure-sensitive stud on the handle.

He watched the others. They manipulated the tool with an effortless, inherited grace, detaching the pearlescent meat from its cartilaginous shell in a single, fluid motion. Kaelen picked up his own, the mechanism feeling clumsy and alien in his battle-scarred hand. His first attempt resulted in a crude tearing, a sound that, in the profound quiet, seemed as loud as a gunshot. A flicker of something—not quite a smile, something colder—touched the lips of the man to his right, a lordling whose pale skin had never known the harshness of an unfiltered sun.

“The Regent must find our provincial fare… unrefined,” Lady Elara’s voice rasped, amplified by her rebreather into a sibilant whisper that cut through the hum. It was not a question.

Kaelen placed the utensil down, deliberately abandoning the pretense. He met her gaze across the abyss of the table. “I have eaten roasted skag-rat in a trench, sustained by recycled water filtered through sand and fear, Lady Vorne,” he said, his voice calm, resonant. “Refinement is a luxury. Sustenance is a necessity. This is sustenance.”

He had broken the cadence, the coded language of insult and insinuation. He had answered a thrust of etiquette with the blunt force of truth. For a moment, the masks of the assembled elite faltered. He saw true expressions: contempt, surprise, and in one or two pairs of eyes, a glimmer of grudging respect. They were predators, testing the strength of the new alpha. They understood only strength.

Lady Elara’s rebreather hissed a long, slow exhalation. The wan light on her temple flickered. “Fear,” she repeated, the word tasting strange in the sterile air. “An ingredient with which we have grown… unfamiliar. Perhaps you will reacquaint us with its flavor.”

The threat was now unveiled, stripped of its silken drapery. This was not about dinner. It was about the soul of this dying planet. They, with their decaying technology and their ossified traditions, were the keepers of its ancient, mystical heart. He was the foreign body, the iron nail driven into the petrified wood of their society. He had conquered their armies and shattered their government, but here, in this sweltering room full of ghosts, he was the one who was besieged. The real war, he understood with a chilling certainty, had only just begun. The heat pressed in, no longer just the planet’s breath, but the weight of a culture determined to suffocate him.

The Grand Refectory of House Valerius did not breathe. Air, thick as silt and smelling of baked silica and generations of cloying incense, was moved by groaning, archaic ventilators, its circulation a parody of life. I felt it press against my skin, a physical weight beneath the starched, unfamiliar fabric of my Regent’s uniform. This room, a cavern carved from the planet’s crimson bedrock, was a monument to a power we had supposedly broken. Its vaulted ceiling, ribbed like the bleached skeleton of some leviathan, was veined with light-strips that flickered with the erratic pulse of a dying heart, casting our long shadows onto the obsidian floor as if we were already ghosts.

My host, Lord Vol-Valerius, sat at the head of the immense table, a man so ancient he seemed less flesh than a careful arrangement of dust and memory. His skin, a tapestry of sun-cracked parchment, was stretched thin over bird-like bones. Only his eyes, sunken in shadowed orbits, held a reptilian vitality, two chips of obsidian scrutinizing my every microscopic adjustment in posture. He was the apex predator of this particular ecosystem, a creature of patience who had outlived rebellions, droughts, and the slow decay of his own world’s magnificent technology. We, the victors of the orbital war, the bringers of a new order, were merely the latest weather pattern to him.

“The Regent finds our customs… austere?” His voice was the dry rasp of sand skittering across glass. It was not a question but a scalpel, probing for the weakness he knew must exist.

Around the table, the others—the last scions of the great houses, the matriarchs of the mining guilds, the high-priests of the Faded Core—paused. Their utensils, wrought from whisper-thin crystal, hovered over their plates. They were a curated audience, a jury of ancestors.

I met his gaze, forcing the muscles of my face into a mask of placid contemplation. On the battlefields of the Ash Wastes, fear had been a clean, sharp thing—the shriek of plasma fire, the shudder of an impact. Here, it was a miasma, a slow-acting poison in the wine. “I find them honest, Lord Valerius. Xylos does not pretend to be a garden. Why should its people?”

A murmur, quieter than the groan of the ventilators, rippled through the guests. A point scored, perhaps, or a misstep. I could not yet read the intricate language of their silences. My second-in-command, Jian, shifted beside me, his own discomfort a palpable heat. He was a soldier, accustomed to unambiguous terrain. This room was a labyrinth of mirrors and mirages.

A servitor-drone, its chrome chassis pitted with age, drifted forward, its anti-grav emitters whining a discordant tune. It placed before each of us a covered dish. The lid was lifted, releasing a plume of vapour that smelled of scorched minerals and something unnervingly alive.

Inside, coiled on a bed of phosphorescent salt, was a creature known as a Sun-Eater. It was a local delicacy, and a test. Its segmented body, the colour of a deep bruise, pulsed with a faint internal light. From its core, a single, crystalline spine jutted upwards, its tip vibrating with a frequency I could feel in my teeth. The custom, as my frantic cultural briefings had informed me, was to sever the spine with a specialized fork, consume the still-quivering nerve cluster, and endure the fleeting, hallucinatory communion with the planet’s deep geothermal consciousness—what the Xylans called the ‘Sand-Song.’ To refuse was an insult. To fail, a confession of weakness.

Valerius picked up his own fork, a trident of sharpened bone. “The flesh sustains the body,” he intoned, the beginning of a ritual grace. “But the Song sustains the soul. It is the truth of this world, written in fire and stone.” He watched me, his old eyes unblinking. He was waiting for the off-worlder, the conqueror, to balk at their pagan communion.

My hand felt heavy, my fingers clumsy as I grasped the fork. My body, a product of sterile orbital habitats and recycled rations, screamed in protest. This was not food; it was a sacrament of a faith I did not share, on a world I had only taken by force. I remembered the red dust of Xylos coating the faces of my dead soldiers, a final, grim anointing. What right did I have to its soul?

Jian’s hand rested for a fraction of a second on my arm, a gesture of solidarity that felt like an anchor in a storm. I gave a minute shake of my head. I had to do this alone.

I mirrored Valerius’s movements, positioning the tines of the fork at the base of the crystalline spine. The vibration intensified, a high-pitched keen that seemed to echo in the hollows of my skull. The other guests were a gallery of statues, their own meals untouched. This was the true theatre. My grip tightened, the bone-handle slick with the sweat of my palm. I pressed down.

There was a sharp crack, like ice fracturing. The light within the Sun-Eater flared violently, then extinguished. The keening stopped. A profound silence descended upon the refectory, broken only by the labouring ventilators.

I raised the nerve cluster to my lips. It was cool, gelatinous, and tasted of ozone and deep earth. As it dissolved on my tongue, the world dissolved with it. The room of stone and shadows vanished, replaced by a searing, incandescent white. I felt not heat, but pressure—the weight of millennia of rock, the slow, tectonic grind of a planet’s heart. There was no sound, yet a voice spoke, a chorus woven from the resonance of stone on stone, of magma flows, of the patient, relentless erosion by the solar winds. It was the Sand-Song. It showed me nothing of the future, nothing of the past, only the immense, geologic *is* of Xylos—its unforgiving, eternal, and utterly alien existence. It was a truth without mercy.

I returned to myself with a gasp, my heart hammering against my ribs. My vision cleared. Lord Valerius was staring at me, his mask of aristocratic indifference fractured by something I had not seen before: the ghost of astonishment. A single drop of blood, dark as wine, trickled from his nostril, a sign of a psychic shock I had somehow passed on to him through the shared ritual.

I placed my fork down on the obsidian table, the sound unnaturally loud in the silent room. I felt a strange calm settle over me, a resonance with the very bedrock beneath my feet. I had not conquered the planet’s soul. I had merely listened to it. And it had found me… adequate.

“The truth,” I said, my voice steady, though my spirit was still reeling from the immensity of the contact, “is often austere.”

Valerius slowly raised a linen napkin to his face, hiding the tell-tale blood. His obsidian eyes no longer held mockery. They held the chilling respect one reserves for an entirely new kind of predator. The war of plasma and steel was over. The war of whispers and souls had just begun.

The heat in Lord Valerius’s salon was not the honest, brutal heat of the Xylan wastes, which seared the lungs and cracked the very stones. This was a different beast entirely: a curated, cloying warmth that clung to the skin like a film of oil, a product of ancient atmospheric regulators humming their dissonant death-song somewhere in the mountain’s core. It was a heat of proximity, of too many powdered faces and whisper-thin silks rustling in a space carved from rust-colored rock, a heat that spoke of power held too long in a decaying world.

From my place at the long, obsidian table, I, Kaelen, Provisional Governor of a world I had conquered but could not yet claim to rule, felt a single bead of sweat trace a cold path from my temple down my jaw. A betrayal. On Xylos, to sweat was to show weakness, to admit the planet was winning. The native elite, arranged around the table like a collection of exquisite, desiccated insects, remained impossibly, unnervingly dry. Their faces, webs of fine lines etched by generations of sipping recycled water, were placid masks.

Lord Valerius, my host, sat at the table’s head. He was a creature of fine bones and papyrus-thin skin, his age impossible to guess. His eyes, the color of the twin moons seen through a dust storm, held a patient, geological stillness. He had not fought our invasion with weapons; he was fighting it now, with crystal goblets and arcane etiquette. Every gesture, every polished phrase, was a carefully aimed projectile.

"Our world offers few luxuries, Governor," Valerius murmured, his voice a dry rasp, like sand skittering across glass. "We have learned to cultivate appreciation for… scarcity. For that which endures the thirst." He made a minute gesture. A servant, silent as a wraith, placed a small, covered bowl before each guest. The porcelain was so thin it was nearly translucent, glowing with the ambient light of the crystalline lamps overhead, which flickered with the inconsistent pulse of a failing power grid.

The air, already thick with the scent of dessicated florals and a metallic tang of ozone, acquired a new note: something loamy, something deep and cold, the smell of a cavern opened for the first time in a millennium. My military training had catalogued a thousand threats, from plasma burns to neurotoxins, yet it had no protocol for this suffocating web of ritual. My hand rested near the hilt of the kinetic pistol holstered beneath my formal tunic, a useless comfort. The true battle was here, waged with posture and appetite.

Valerius lifted his cover. "The Ghost-Fungus of the Deeps," he announced, a current of reverence rippling through his Xylan guests. "It fruits only in absolute darkness, nurtured by mineral seeps a kilometer below the surface. A delicacy of… resonance."

I stared into my bowl. Coiled upon a bed of glistening, black grains was something that defied simple description. It was a lattice of phosphorescent mycelium, glowing with a soft, internal blue light, its structure both fungal and crystalline. It seemed to pulse, a slow, hypnotic rhythm that resonated not in the eye, but somewhere deeper, in the bones of the skull. This was the test. Not a poison, nothing so crude. This was a trial by culture, by spirit. To refuse was an insult of unimaginable gravity. To partake was to ingest the very soul of this alien, arid world.

The others lifted their forks—three-tined instruments of silvered bone—with a fluid, synchronized grace. I watched their technique, the precise angle of approach, the way they severed a small portion without disturbing the whole. My own hand, calloused and scarred from a dozen campaigns, felt brutish and clumsy wrapped around the delicate instrument. The silence in the salon deepened, becoming a physical substance, a pressure against the eardrums, thick with the unsaid histories of a thousand such dinners where fortunes were unmade between one course and the next.

I raised the fork. My throat was a desert.

The Ghost-Fungus had no texture in the conventional sense. As it touched my tongue, it dissolved, not into liquid, but into sensation. A shock, not of taste, but of *memory*. Coldness flooded my senses—the patient, abiotic chill of deep rock. I felt the immense, slow pressure of the planet’s crust, the memory of a million-year drought locked in every crystal of the stone around me. A phantom thirst, ancient and profound, clawed at my throat, a thirst for oceans that had boiled away before my species had learned to walk upright.

Images, unbidden, flooded my mind’s eye: the whisper-thin skeletons of leviathans buried beneath the dunes, the faint, psychic echo of a forgotten ecosystem, the loneliness of a sun-bleached world dreaming of rain. It was the planet’s grief, its deep and abiding sorrow, distilled into a single, overwhelming mouthful. My heart hammered against my ribs, a frantic, fleshy drum against the silent, mineral dirge. I fought the instinct to recoil, to gasp, to betray the torrent roaring through my consciousness. I forced my features into a mask of placid consideration, mimicking the faint, appreciative tilt of the head I saw in the man opposite me.

My gaze locked with Valerius’s across the shimmering length of the table. His expression was unreadable, yet I sensed a shift. It was not approval, not yet. It was the subtle recalibration of a master strategist who has just seen his opponent counter an unexpected move. He had expected me to be a simple soldier, a creature of blast-shields and logistics. He had not expected a man who could swallow the soul of his world and not flinch.

I inclined my head, a gesture of thanks, a parody of his own elegance. The effort was monumental. The fungal resonance still echoed through me, a cold, blue light behind my eyes. I felt the immense weight of the rock above us, the endless sand beyond, the ghost of a dead ocean within me.

"A unique flavor," I managed, my voice sounding distant, fractured. "It has… depth."

Lord Valerius’s lips stretched into something that might, on a kinder world, have been a smile. Here, on Xylos, it was a fissure opening in sun-baked clay, revealing nothing but shadow beneath. "Indeed, Governor," he whispered. "Everything of value on our world does."

The air in Baron Valerius’s dining cavern was a physical weight, thick with the scent of ozone from the overworked atmosphere condensers and the cloying sweetness of xeric blooms whose brief, violent lives were spent in crystal vases. Kaia felt the heat not as a blanket but as a presence, a sentience that pressed against the fine-spun synth-silk of her borrowed gubernatorial gown, a garment that felt more like a cage than a symbol of her new, precipitous power. Outside, the twin ochre suns of Syrna were setting, casting the blasted landscape in shades of blood and rust; inside, holographic dust motes, programmed to mimic the swirling nebulae of a forgotten Earth, danced in the chthonic glow of the recessed lighting.

Her host, the last of the great Cinder-Barons, Lord Aris Thorne, sat at the head of a table carved from a single slab of obsidian. His face, a cartography of genteel cruelty, was all sharp angles and thin, bloodless lips. He had not fought their revolution. He had watched it, a patient predator from his fortified spire, and when the old regime had crumbled into the ever-present dust, he had been the first to extend an invitation. A welcome. A test.

“Our new Governor is unused to the cool of the deep-caverns,” Thorne’s voice was a sibilant whisper, a sound like sand skittering over glass. “We forget, those of us born to the rock, how the surface heat leaches the strength from off-world bone.”

He had not said *off-world*, but the implication hung in the air alongside the shimmering heat-haze. Kaia felt her partner, Kael, shift beside her, his own discomfort a palpable thing. He was the sword, the strategist who had shattered the Barons’ private armies; she was the voice, the mind that had to now weave a peace from the bloody threads of war. His hand, calloused and sure, found hers beneath the table, a small anchor in this treacherous sea of etiquette.

The first course arrived, borne on silent, levitating platters. Translucent jellies shivered in porcelain bowls, each containing a single, bioluminescent grub, its inner light pulsing in a slow, hypnotic rhythm. A delicacy of the deep desert, a food of the elite. To refuse was an insult. To eat with anything less than performative reverence, a sign of barbarism.

Kaia lifted the mother-of-pearl spoon, its weight unfamiliar in her hand. The spoon, she knew from the hurried lessons with their one defected courtier, must not touch the sides of the bowl. The grub must be consumed whole, its light extinguished in a single, fluid motion. She watched Thorne. He raised his spoon with the languid grace of a man who had performed this ritual ten thousand times, his eyes—dark, obsidian chips—never leaving hers. He was not merely eating; he was issuing a challenge, a microscopic political gambit played out with invertebrate larvae.

She met his gaze, held it, and swallowed the creature. It was cool, then burst on her tongue with a flavor like static and cold minerals, the light a phantom flare behind her eyes. A murmur of something—approval, perhaps, or merely surprise—rippled through the dozen other guests, ancient scions of mining dynasties and water-purification cartels whose allegiances were as shifting as the dunes themselves.

The conversation was a weaponized tapestry of allusion and insinuation. They spoke of condenser maintenance schedules, of rogue AI in the forgotten lower levels of the capital, of the subtle variations in the new harvest of Cinder-Lichen. Every topic was a minefield. To admit ignorance of condenser mechanics was to reveal a fatal weakness in resource management. To dismiss the AI threat was to appear naive. And the Cinder-Lichen… the Lichen was foundational. It was the source of the Barons’ wealth, a psychoactive fungus that grew only in the planet’s deepest geothermal vents, a sacrament and a narcotic that underpinned their entire mystical-industrial complex.

“The quality of the recent harvest,” said a woman down the table, her face a mask of powdered alabaster and surgical perfection, “lacks the… resonance of the old strains. Before the… upheaval.”

The word *upheaval* was a stone dropped into a still pool. Kael’s jaw tightened. He saw an accusation of mismanagement; Kaia saw the true test beginning.

“Change is often a catalyst for unforeseen reactions in the planetary biome,” Kaia replied, her voice steady, betraying none of the frantic calculations in her mind. “The deep earth is sensitive. It feels the tremors on the surface.”

Thorne inclined his head, a gesture of concession so minuscule it was nearly imperceptible. “A poetic sentiment, Governor. But poetry does not calibrate the refinement process. For that, one needs a… finer touch. An attunement.”

The final course was brought forth. Not on a platter, but in a single, ornate cryo-casket that hissed vapor as it opened. Inside, nestled on a bed of black velvet, lay a shard of raw Cinder-Lichen. It was beautiful and terrible, a fractal lattice of crystalline filaments that seemed to drink the light, pulsing with a faint, internal violet energy. The ritual of the Lichen was the true heart of any such gathering, a shared hallucinogenic communion meant to forge bonds and expose weaknesses.

A silver tong, wielded by Thorne himself, divided the shard. A piece for each guest, placed in a small chalice of spun metal. This was the moment her tutor had warned her of. The Lichen did not merely alter perception; it was said to shear away the walls of the self, to briefly meld the consciousness of those who partook. In that shared mental space, a lie was a raw wound, a hidden fear a beacon. For a revolutionary posing as a ruler, it was an executioner’s block.

Kael’s hand tightened on hers. *We don’t have to do this,* his grip said.

*We have no choice,* hers replied.

She lifted the chalice. The Lichen smelled of hot rock and something ancient, like the air from a long-sealed tomb. She placed the shard on her tongue. It was not a taste but a texture, a vibration, a key turning a lock deep within her skull.

The room dissolved.

The faces of the Barons blurred, their silks and jewels melting into the heat-shimmer. The sub-audible thrum of the condensers became a roar, the heartbeat of the planet itself. She felt the immense, crushing pressure of the rock above, the furnace of the mantle below. And in the shared, silent space that opened in her mind, she felt the others. Thorne’s consciousness was a cold, polished spire of patient ambition. The woman of powdered alabaster was a vortex of calculated fear. Others were shimmering networks of greed, of nostalgia, of brittle pride.

They searched her mind, their collective will a thousand tiny scalpels seeking the soft tissue of her inadequacy, her off-worlder strangeness. They expected to find the grit of the mining camps, the fury of the rebellion.

Instead, Kaia did not fight. She did not build walls. She let the Lichen carry her deeper. Past her own memories of fire and rhetoric, past Kael’s solid presence, down into the planet’s own slow, geologic consciousness. She offered them not her own history, but Syrna’s. She let them feel the tectonic strain, the thirst of the deep aquifers, the patient, silent growth of the Lichen in the dark. She became a conduit for the planet they claimed to rule but only strip-mined.

For a timeless moment, there was only the shared, raw truth of the world.

When reality reasserted itself, the cavern was silent. The holographic stars had ceased their dance. No one moved. Kaia looked at Thorne. His composure was, for the first time, fractured. The obsidian chips of his eyes held a new light—not respect, not yet, but a flicker of profound, unsettling recognition. He had reached into her mind to find a barbarian and had instead touched the soul of the very world he stood upon.

The silence stretched, a thing with teeth. Kaia knew she had not won. She had merely survived the opening salvo by revealing a weapon they had not known she possessed. And in the chill that now pervaded the cavern, a cold that had nothing to do with the condensers, she understood that the war for Syrna had only just begun.

TOPIC: A dinner party where the new rulers try to navigate the complex politics and etiquette of the planet's elite class. | VERSION: 7
