--------------------
The wind against the Plasteel ramparts of Aethelburg was no mere gale; it was a physical sermon on planetary wrath. It spoke in a million granular voices, a vitreous maelstrom that scoured the last of the gilt from the city’s decaying spires and carried the scent of deep-desert ozone, of stone baked for millennia under a relentless sun. Sergeant Kaelen tasted glass on his teeth. The storm had a flavour, a mineral tang that promised dissolution.

Through the shrieking shroud, Aethelburg’s perimeter lights stuttered like dying embers, their energy fields buckling under the atmospheric assault. His enviro-suit’s chronometer glowed a placid green against his wrist, a ludicrous counterpoint to the chaos. Inside these walls, the Proconsul and his gilded council likely debated tariffs, oblivious to the fact their entire world was being unwritten by the wind. Kaelen gripped the stock of his plasma rifle, the polymer warm and slick with atomized moisture. He felt less a soldier than a priest tending a forgotten altar, his faith eroded to the bone.

Then came a sound beneath the storm’s high keening.

It was not a sound for ears, but for the marrow. A low, resonant thrumming that vibrated up through the ferrocrete foundations of the wall, through the soles of his mag-boots, and into the cage of his ribs. It was a bass note of impossible depth, the hum of continental plates shifting, the groan of a world turning in its sleep. The other sentries on the parapet felt it too. Their practiced postures slackened, heads tilting as if trying to catch a whisper in a hurricane.

“Seismic?” muttered Lyra beside him, her voice a tinny rasp over the comm.

Kaelen didn't answer. He knew the planet's tectonics. This was not the earth. This was life.

Out of the ochre tumult, they materialized. Not all at once, but as apparitions gaining substance, gargantuan silhouettes resolving from the storm’s particulate chaos. The Silicate Leviathans. The Grave-Wyrms of the deep sands. To call them creatures was a failure of language. They were mobile geology, mountains of chert and obsidian and compressed sand given a malevolent, singular purpose. Each one was a cathedral of grinding, crystalline plates, its hide reflecting the failing city lights in a thousand fractured shards. Their progress was slow, inexorable, the very sand before them vitrifying into dark glass from the sheer pressure and friction of their passage.

And upon their backs, clinging to chitinous ridges and ancient, symbiotic flora, were the nomads. The Children of the Unseen Wind. Figures wrapped in sand-bleached cloth, their faces obscured by filtration masks and wind-polished goggles. They carried no plasma rifles, only long, obsidian-bladed spears and the unshakeable gravity of their conviction. They did not ride the leviathans as masters; they were acolytes upon their living gods.

“Hostiles!” Lyra’s shout was almost immediately swallowed by a concussive blast.

The city’s auto-turrets, relics of a more potent technological age, woke with a screech of long-dormant servos. Streams of super-heated plasma, incandescent blue against the swirling dun, lanced into the nearest leviathan. The bolts struck its flank with the wet percussion of lightning hitting water. Steam and vaporized rock erupted, yet the creature did not even shudder. The impact sites glowed cherry-red for a moment, then cooled to black scars on a hide that measured its age in geological epochs. It was like throwing stones at a glacier.

The lead leviathan reached the city wall. There was no bellow of challenge, no monstrous roar. Only the deafening crunch of its immense forward mandible closing upon the ferrocrete. The wall, engineered to withstand orbital bombardment, groaned like a dying beast. Metal shrieked as it tore. Plasteel vaporized. A ten-metre section of the rampart, Kaelen’s section, simply ceased to exist, collapsing into a chasm of pulverized stone and dust.

He was falling, tumbling through a world of noise and grit and the gut-wrenching sensation of weightlessness. He landed hard, the suit’s impact gel saving his bones but not his breath. The air punched from his lungs. He lay gasping, his helmet’s display a spiderweb of fracture-cracks. Through them, he saw the sky: a vortex of angry rust.

The nomads were descending. They flowed from the leviathan’s back like a tide of ghosts, their movements fluid and silent in the howling wind. Kaelen scrambled for his rifle, his training a desperate instinct clawing its way through the shock. He brought the weapon up, its targeting reticle flickering erratically. A figure loomed over him, spear raised. The spear’s tip was not merely sharp; it was a sliver of the planet’s heart, impossibly black.

Kaelen fired. The plasma bolt caught the nomad in the chest. There was a hiss, a brief, violent incandescence, and the figure collapsed. There was no satisfaction, only a hollow sickness. Another nomad took their place, and another. They were not an army; they were a litany, a physical prayer.

He fought his way to his feet, falling back with Lyra and the handful of other survivors toward the inner bastion. The battle was a fever dream. The precise, geometric lines of Imperial military doctrine dissolved against the nomads' ecstatic frenzy. They fought not with tactics, but with a kind of tectonic fury, as if they were conduits for the planet’s own rage.

He saw one of them, a woman whose goggles had been shattered, revealing eyes of startling, lapis-lazuli blue—the color of those who drank only reclaimed water their whole lives. She was not looking at the soldiers. Her gaze was fixed on the leviathan now pushing its monumental head through the breach, its multifaceted eyes like clusters of black diamonds. Her lips moved, and though he could not hear the words, he understood their shape. It was a name. She was speaking its name.

In that instant, Kaelen understood the political fiction of Aethelburg. The city was a parasite, its technology a brittle shell clinging to a world that had never accepted it. This was not an invasion. It was an immune response. The nomads and their colossal gods were the antibodies, come to purge a sickness that had festered for too long. He looked from the crumbling spires behind him to the impossible creature before him—a being whose life force was the planet’s own. He felt the rifle in his hands, a tool of a dead faith, and knew, with a certainty as profound and terrifying as the storm itself, that he was on the wrong side of history. Not history as written in the data-slates of men, but the deep, lithic history of the world itself.

Here is a chapter of a science fiction novel based on your scene and rules.

***

**Chapter 7: The K’tharr of Dust and Kings**

The air in the Grand Chamber of Arrak was a physical presence, a weight of heat and history that pressed upon my skin. Thick as spun glass, it shimmered under the dying glow-panels studding the vaulted ceiling, each one a jaundiced eye gazing down upon the circle of judgment. Here, deep within the planet’s crust, the furnace breath of the geothermal vents was a constant reminder of the world’s molten heart, a world that cared little for the transient dramas of the men who scuttled across its surface. Dust, the fine ochre powder that was our planet’s truest sovereign, coated everything: the dull patina of the obsidian throne, the corroded chrome of the silent servitors lining the walls, the very back of my throat.

Before me, Rhys waited. He did not stand so much as coil, a length of wired muscle and casual cruelty poured into the severe black uniform of House Harkon. The vibro-glaive in his hand was an extension of his will, its blade a sliver of polished obsidian whose monomolecular edge hummed with a subsonic threat that vibrated through the flagstones and up into the bones of my feet. A smile, thin as a fissure in rock, played on his lips. It was a performer’s smile, meant for the gallery of his uncle’s retainers who watched from the shadowed colonnades—a silent chorus of vultures.

“You feel it, don’t you, Kaelen?” His voice was a rasp, filed sharp by the dry air and a lifetime of condescension. “The legacy. A ponderous thing. It will slow your arm. It will dull your eye.”

I offered no reply. My own glaive, *Sand-Drinker*, felt cool and solid in my grip, its leather-wrapped hilt worn smooth by the hands of my father and his father before him. Its weight was a familiar anchor in the swirling currents of fear and duty. I drew a breath, tasting the scent of scorched metal from the failing climate recyclers and the faint, spicy aroma of the sacred *kai* blossoms wilting in their ceremonial urns. The K’tharr, the duel of succession, had its own liturgy, and silence was my part.

He moved first. Not a charge, but a slithering, liquid advance that ate the distance between us. His glaive led, a serpent’s tongue tasting the air. I met his initial probe with a low block, the impact a jarring shock that raced up my arm. An ozone-blue arc flared where the energy fields of our blades repulsed one another, the sound a sibilant hiss of stressed metal that was swallowed by the chamber’s oppressive acoustics.

Rhys was a storm of precise, economical violence. He fought without honor, but with a terrifying efficiency. Each parry I made was met with a counter-thrust aimed not for a killing blow, but for a smaller, more intimate wound—a slice at the tendon, a feint toward the eye. He was a dissector, seeking to unmake me piece by piece. The thrum of our weapons became a predatory duet. Sweat traced corrosive paths through the ritual chalk markings on my face, stinging my eyes. The heat was a living thing now, wrapping itself around my chest, squeezing the air from my lungs.

Time stretched thin as a wire. The faces in the shadows blurred into a single, malevolent presence. There was only the circle, the heat, and Rhys’s pale, mocking eyes. He disengaged with a dancer’s grace, leaving me breathing in ragged bursts.

“Is this the might of House Atreus?” he taunted, his voice echoing slightly in the immense room. “A legacy of defense? Of waiting? Our Baron understands the truth of this world, Kaelen. One does not wait for the storm. One *is* the storm.”

He came again, faster this time. His blade was a flickering silver thread weaving a pattern of death. A high block, a spin, a low parry—I was a mechanism of reaction, my body recalling long hours of training in the geothermal practice grottos. But he was relentless. He forced me back, step by grinding step, toward the dais of the Obsidian Throne. A sudden, vicious feint drew my guard high, and in that splinter of a second, his true strike came from below.

Pain, white-hot and absolute, exploded in my left thigh. I saw the dark blossom of red on my grey trousers before I truly felt the wet, searing heat of it. A gasp was torn from my throat. The coppery tang of my own blood filled the air. I stumbled, my balance compromised, and the retainers of House Harkon murmured with a sound like grinding stone, a collective rumble of satisfaction.

Rhys halted, lowering his glaive to admire his work. The sadism in his gaze was pure and unfiltered. “The first cut is the deepest,” he whispered, though the words carried across the silent hall. “A taste of your own mortality. Your House builds on sand, Kaelen. One good kick, and it all comes down.”

It was then, on one knee, with the fire in my leg threatening to consume my reason, that the other sound began. It was not a sound for the ears, but for the soul. A low, pervasive hum, deeper than the thrum of the glaives, older than the groaning machinery of the palace. It was the Song of the Sands, the planet’s ancient, dreaming mind. I had felt it before, in moments of deep meditation or fever, a resonance that connected the living marrow of my bones to the planet’s iron core.

The pain did not vanish, but it found its place within a larger pattern. The heat was no longer an enemy, but the blood of the world. The dust motes dancing in the light were not signs of decay, but a swirling galaxy of possibilities. My perception shifted. I saw Rhys not as a man of flesh and blood, but as a discordant note in the planet’s song—a shriek of ambition and hate. I saw the ghost-image of his next attack before he even began to move, a shimmering line of intent in the super-heated air.

He lunged, aiming for my throat, a final, arrogant flourish.

I did not rise to meet him. I flowed. Pushing off my good leg, I pivoted on my wounded one, the pain a fulcrum for my motion. The movement was not learned; it was given. *Sand-Drinker* came around not in a block, but in a sweeping, upward arc that was less a strike and more an answer. It was the curve of a scythe harvesting grain, the inevitable sweep of a dune cresting in the wind.

My blade met no resistance. The energy field of Rhys’s glaive was misaligned by a hair’s breadth, a fatal imprecision born of his overconfidence. My own monomolecular edge passed through the soft tissue of his neck with a sound like tearing silk.

For an eternal second, nothing happened. Rhys’s forward momentum carried him past me, his eyes wide with a profound and terminal surprise. The arrogant smile was frozen on his face, a mask of disbelief. Then, a thin, ruby line appeared on his throat. He brought a hand to it, confused. He took one more stumbling step before his body forgot how to live. He fell with a wet, percussive sound that seemed impossibly loud.

The profound, ringing silence that followed was a physical blow. The Song of the Sands receded, leaving me gasping, leaning on my glaive, my leg a column of agony. The Harkon retainers were statues carved from shadow and disbelief. My own people were just as still.

Rhys lay at the foot of the Obsidian Throne. A dark pool, far darker than the polished stone, began to spread around his head. I had not won a duel. I had fulfilled a prophecy written in blood and dust. I had answered the planet’s song. And as I looked at the empty throne, I felt not the triumph of victory, but the crushing, desolate weight of the crown I had just claimed.

TOPIC: The duel between the heir and the sadistic nephew of the enemy baron in the throne room. | VERSION: 2

The Great Chamber of the Sun-Stone offered no respite from the perpetual furnace of Eremus. Heat, thick as silt, pressed in through the fractured crysteel dome, a celestial wound through which the jaundiced eye of the primary sun stared. It baked the silence, bleaching the sound from the air until all that remained was the low, thrumming resonance of the palace’s failing atmospheric processors—a death rattle echoing through halls of forgotten grandeur. Dust, the planet’s ubiquitous sacrament, coated the gilded reliefs of forgotten dynasts and settled in the chiseled hollows of the empty throne.

My name is Kaelen, and I stood on the precipice of my own extinction.

Before me, across the inlaid circle of obsidian that served as the dueling floor, stood Vorlag. Nephew to the usurper Baron Fenris, he was a monument to genetic brutality. His musculature coiled beneath a synth-dermal sheath, a canvas of shimmering black ligaments and augmetic sinew. A rictus of anticipated pleasure twisted his lips, a grotesque counterpoint to the ossified stillness of the assembled court, their faces impassive masks in the brittle light. They were vultures robed in finery, waiting for the carrion.

The terms of this *Trial by Blade* were absolute, a relic of an honor our houses had long since shed. My victory would halt the Baron’s claim on the Atreides Spiceworks—a temporary reprieve. My death would legitimize it entirely. Politics rendered down to the sharpened edge.

I drew my ancestral blade. Not with a flourish, but with the weary reverence one affords a sacred, burdensome thing. The hilt, wrapped in the cured hide of a sand-wyrm, felt like an extension of my own bones. I thumbed the activation rune. With a hum that vibrated deep in my teeth, a filament of incandescent energy erupted, coalescing into a blade of pure, contained sunlight. Its heat washed over my face, a familiar, predatory warmth. The air around it shimmered, distorting Vorlag’s sneer into something even more monstrous.

“The little prince and his glowing heirloom,” Vorlag’s voice was a gravel-slide, amplified by a subtle vocalizer. “Does it whisper secrets of your dead father to you, Kaelen?”

I offered no reply. Words were a currency for the weak in this room. Here, only the physics of violence held sway. My focus narrowed, sinking past the taunt, past the oppressive heat, past the expectant silence. I sought the planet’s own pulse, the deep, slow rhythm that the mystics called the Song of the Sands. It was a vibration I’d been trained since birth to feel, a frequency that hummed just beneath the threshold of hearing, a current in the great, silent ocean of the desert. It was there, faint but insistent, a promise of clarity in the coming chaos.

Vorlag’s blade, a cruel, jagged thing of cobalt plasma, shrieked into existence. He lunged.

It was not a swordsman’s lunge, elegant and precise; it was the charge of a predator, a brute-force meteor carving a shimmering blue arc through the dust-moted air. The Song of the Sands crescendoed in my marrow. It did not tell me to block, to parry. It whispered: *yield*.

I flowed backward, my boots scudding silently on the polished obsidian, the edge of his blade hissing inches from my chest. The wave of displaced, superheated air scorched my tunic. He overextended, his momentum a clumsy, powerful thing. I pivoted, my own blade tracing a fluid, economical arc—not at his body, but at the augmetic cabling exposed at his elbow. A spray of sparks, a howl of ozone, and his arm locked, twitching.

Rage contorted his face. The sadist’s pleasure had vanished, replaced by the pure, ugly fury of a thwarted bully. He compensated with his other arm, swinging his weapon in a wide, horizontal scythe meant to cleave me in two.

Again, the Song. *Descend*.

I dropped, the world tilting, the cobalt hiss of his blade passing over my head so closely I felt the static charge raise the hair on my arms. From my crouch, I thrust upward. Not a killing blow, but a strategic one. The tip of my blade scored a deep, molten groove across his armored thigh, severing a power conduit. A section of his leg went limp, and he stumbled, his balance compromised.

He roared, a sound of pure, mechanical frustration, and slammed the pommel of his weapon into the floor. The obsidian cracked. He was all power, no artistry. He believed the duel was a matter of overwhelming force, a simple equation of energy applied until one body broke. He did not understand. This was not a test of strength. It was a conversation with death, and only one of us spoke its language.

The heat in the chamber intensified, my own body a furnace. Sweat slicked my grip on the hilt. My lungs burned, each breath a draft of fire. I could feel my reserves dwindling, the strain of channeling the Song leaving a hollow ache behind my eyes. Vorlag, though wounded and clumsy, was a machine built for endurance. He began to press his advantage, his wild, powerful swings forcing me into a constant, draining retreat. A searing line of pain erupted along my ribs as the edge of his blade grazed me—a shallow cut, but its cauterizing touch sent a shock of agony through my system.

My vision swam. The faces of the court blurred into a smear of pale judgment. The Song of the Sands became a discordant shriek. I was losing the connection, drowning in the noise of my own pain and exhaustion.

Vorlag saw it. His eyes, cold cybernetic lenses, narrowed. The sadistic smile returned. He knew he had me. He stalked forward, blade held high for the final, brutal stroke.

It was then, in that moment of absolute despair, that I let go. I stopped fighting the pain, stopped straining to hear the Song. I simply… listened. And beneath the clamor, beneath the thundering of my own heart, it was there. Not a whisper, but a silent, undeniable gravity. The planet. The dust. The heat. My ancestors, their essence lingering in the ancient steel I held. We were all part of the same inevitable tide.

Vorlag lunged.

My body moved without conscious thought, an instrument of the deep rhythm. My feet did not retreat; they planted. My blade did not rise to block; it dropped. As his cobalt weapon descended, I twisted, not away from him, but into him, my body a hair's breadth from his. My sun-blade, held in a low, reversed grip, slid upward. It was not a slash or a thrust. It was an offering.

It found the unarmored space beneath his jaw, the soft vulnerability where the augmetics met the man.

There was no scream. Only a soft, wet sizzle, a final, choked exhalation of superheated air. The light in Vorlag’s cybernetic eyes flickered and died. His massive body swayed for a moment, a felled colossus, before crashing to the obsidian floor with a sound that shattered the chamber’s oppressive silence.

The cobalt blade winked out. The Song receded, leaving me hollow, a mere vessel of flesh and bone, trembling in the vast, unforgiving silence I had just purchased with blood. I stood over my fallen foe, my own blade still humming, its light casting my long, solitary shadow across the silent, watching vultures of the court and the empty, waiting throne.

TOPIC: The duel between the heir and the sadistic nephew of the enemy baron in the throne room. | VERSION: 3
--------------------
The throne room of Arrakis was a tomb for a dying star. Light, the colour of bleached bone, poured through slanted crystalline apertures, striking motes of silica dust that danced in the superheated air like frantic, microscopic ghosts. The air itself, a kiln-fired presence thick with the ghosts of ozone and the planet’s perpetual rust, did not stir; it pressed, a physical weight upon Kaelen’s shoulders as he faced the Baron’s progeny.

Before them, the Obsidian Throne sat vacant, a shard of solidified night that seemed to drink the very light from the chamber. It was upon its glitching, holographic dais that this matter of succession, of water rights and celestial sovereignty, would be settled. Not by treaty, but by the ancient, brutal calculus of the K’tharr—the trial by resonance blade.

Kaelen’s own blade was alive in his hand. Not with heat, but with a thrumming, sympathetic vibration that coursed up his arm, a low G-sharp that was the frequency of his own bloodline. The hilt, wrapped in the tanned hide of a sand-serpent, was slick with his sweat. The blade itself, a meter of contained stellar fury, projected a field of coherent, shimmering cyan—the colour of a deep, impossible ocean. It was a weapon of focus, of discipline. A scalpel.

Across the polished basalt floor, Valerius grinned. His blade was a jagged, unstable crimson, the colour of a fresh wound. It spat miniature solar flares and hissed, its resonance a chaotic arpeggio of discordance that grated on the inner ear. Where Kaelen stood with the rigid economy of a desert hawk, Valerius slouched, a predator assured of his meal. His face, all sharp angles and cruel indulgence, was a mask of aristocratic disdain. He was not here to win; he was here to perform an vivisection.

“The little Atreides heir,” Valerius purred, his voice amplified by the room’s acoustics. “Come to claim a throne your father’s bones couldn’t hold. Shall we see if your viscera shows more fortitude?”

Kaelen offered no reply. Words were a currency Valerius spent with profligate waste. Kaelen had only one offering to make. He shifted his weight, the grit of sand scraping under his boot, the sound a sacrilege in the humming silence. He let the heat of the twin suns beating on the dome above become a part of him, a furnace to temper his will. He saw not the sneering nephew, but a geometry of failure, a series of flawed angles waiting to be exploited.

Valerius lunged. Not a simple thrust, but a theatrical, spinning assault, his crimson blade carving a broad, incandescent arc designed to intimidate. It was the movement of a man who had only ever fought frightened slaves in a palace pit. Kaelen didn't retreat. He flowed, a half-step to the left, his own cyan blade rising not to block, but to guide.

The shriek of their resonant fields meeting was a physical blow, a high-frequency scream that vibrated through the floor and into Kaelen’s teeth. Ozone, sharp and metallic, flooded his nostrils. He saw the flicker of surprise in Valerius’s eyes, a momentary confusion that a target had not simply cowered. Kaelen used the deflection to pivot, his blade tracing a tight, precise loop that aimed for the exposed wrist.

Valerius was fast. He yanked his arm back, the crimson field searing the air where his flesh had been. He laughed, a dry, grating sound. “Clever! A little desert viper, all coiled and ready to strike. But I am a fire-drake, boy. I burn vipers from their nests.”

He came again, a flurry of attacks this time, a storm of jagged energy. He fought with a sadist’s passion, each swing a caress of promised agony, each parry a frustrated snarl. Kaelen became a study in negation. He was the void into which Valerius’s fury disappeared. His movements were minimal, his parries mere whispers of contact, turning the brute force of the crimson blade with the fine-tuned edge of his own. The throne room filled with the percussive, atonal music of their duel, a symphony of imminent death.

The heat was a living thing now, coiling in Kaelen’s lungs. He could feel the failing atmospheric converters struggling against the combined output of their blades. He saw the silent, impassive figures of the court shimmer through the thermal haze: his own retainers, their faces taut with fear; and Baron Harkonnen, a bloated, obscene mountain of flesh floating in his suspensor chair, watching his nephew’s blood sport with the placid curiosity of a god observing insects.

Valerius was growing angry. The performance was not proceeding as planned. The heir was not bleeding, not screaming. He was simply… enduring.

“Tired, little mouse?” Valerius hissed, his face slick with a sheen of sweat that was not entirely from the heat. He feinted high, then dropped into a low, sweeping cut meant to sever Kaelen’s leg at the knee.

Kaelen had anticipated it. He felt it not in his eyes, but in the subtle shift of Valerius’s blade-resonance, a greedy, downward plunge in its chaotic song. Instead of leaping back, Kaelen dropped with the attack, his left hand bracing against the hot floor as he spun on his heel. His cyan blade, held low, came up in an inverted arc.

It was not a killing blow. It was an insult.

The cyan field sliced through the fine-spun fabric of Valerius’s tunic, scoring a shallow, bloodless, cauterized line across his chest. A gasp went through the assembled court.

Valerius froze, his eyes dropping to the glowing thread of ruin on his uniform. The sneer vanished, replaced by a mask of pure, homicidal rage. The chaotic resonance of his blade sharpened into a singular, piercing shriek. The sadist was gone, and only the butcher remained.

This was the moment Kaelen had manufactured. The moment a mind consumed by rage forgets its geometry.

Valerius charged, a mindless bull, his crimson blade held high for a final, cleaving strike. There was no finesse, no art, only the overwhelming desire to obliterate.

Kaelen stood his ground. He quieted the hum of his own weapon, sinking his consciousness into the still point at its heart. The world slowed. The roar of Valerius’s charge became a distant drone. The oppressive heat was a cool bath. He saw the opening—not a grand, cinematic space, but a sliver of opportunity, a fractional moment between the downward swing of Valerius’s arms and the forward momentum of his body.

He did not step forward. He simply extended his arm.

His cyan blade, now humming with a quiet, deadly focus, did not meet the crimson storm. It slid beneath it. The tip, a point of pure, cerulean finality, entered Valerius’s torso just below the sternum, parting muscle and synth-fibre with frictionless ease.

Valerius’s momentum carried him forward, impaling himself fully. His bellow of rage became a wet, shocked cough. The crimson blade winked out of existence, its dissonant shriek silenced. The only sound was the deep, constant thrum of Kaelen’s blade, now buried to the hilt in his enemy.

For a heartbeat, they were locked in a grotesque embrace. Kaelen could feel the frantic, failing pulse of the man through the hilt of his weapon. He saw the disbelief in Valerius’s eyes curdle into the stark, absolute terror of oblivion.

Kaelen retracted his blade.

Valerius collapsed, a puppet with its strings cut. The silence that descended upon the throne room was more profound than any sound, broken only by the faint, electrical crackle from the vacant, judging throne.

TOPIC: The duel between the heir and the sadistic nephew of the enemy baron in the throne room. | VERSION: 4
--------------------
The throne was a relic of silent thunder, a mass of fused crysteel and obsidian that had not known an occupant for three generations. It dominated the Grand Chamber of Aethel, its dead circuits dreaming of starlight. Around it, the chamber itself was a study in magnificent decay. Crystalline panes, meant to polarize the brutal glare of the twin suns, were fractured, allowing spears of white-hot light to impale the mosaic floor, illuminating motes of ochre dust that danced like frantic, ephemeral ghosts. The air, thick with the scent of ozone from failing atmospheric regulators and the dry, mineral tang of the planet itself, was a physical weight.

Kaelen felt the grit of that world under the thin soles of his boots. He felt the thrum of its deep, geothermal heart through the stone, a slow, resonant pulse that was the only true sovereign of this desiccated land. Before him, Valerius paced, a predator testing the limits of a cage. Valerius, nephew to the usurper Baron Hark, was a creature of chrome and cruelty. Where Kaelen wore the simple, dun-colored robes of his ascetic lineage, Valerius was clad in articulated plates of polished armor that mirrored the dying light with arrogant fidelity. A network of shimmering conduits pulsed beneath the metal, a testament to the off-world augments that fueled his unnatural speed and strength.

“The air grows thin, little heir,” Valerius purred, his voice a synthetic rasp amplified by a hidden vocoder. He spun his weapon, a resonant vibro-glaive that whined a hungry, dissonant chord. “Or is that just the blood leaving your head? It is a long way down from the heights of nobility.”

Kaelen did not answer. He held his own blade, a phase-falx, its monomolecular edge shimmering but silent. It was an ancestral weapon, its power drawn not from a disposable energy cell but from the wielder’s own bio-electric field. To hold it was to feel a faint, cool drain, a constant reminder of the price of its lethality. He centered himself, breathing in the heat, letting the planet’s deep hum resonate in his bones. This duel, the K’tharr, was not a matter of honor; honor was a currency of a more verdant age. This was a political necessity, a ritualized assassination under the gaze of silent, impassive courtiers who lined the chamber’s perimeter, their faces shadowed and unreadable.

Valerius lunged. Not with the calculated grace of a trained duelist, but with the explosive violence of a malfunctioning engine. He was a storm of motion, the whining glaive a silver blur carving arcs of displaced air. Kaelen moved with him, not countering, but flowing. His feet slid across the sandy mosaic, a dancer in a rite of death. The falx rose, not to meet the glaive’s fury head-on, but to deflect, to guide.

The clang was not metal on metal. It was a shearing shriek, a sound of physics being violated as the two energy fields scraped against one another. A shower of blue-white sparks erupted, their ephemeral brilliance casting Valerius’s face in a demonic glare. His smile was a gash, all teeth and malice. He pressed the attack, a relentless piston of blows, each one meant not merely to kill but to maim, to shatter, to dominate. The air grew thick with the smell of super-heated metal and the acrid tang of vaporized stone where his wild swings scored the floor.

Kaelen was a rock in that furious tide. He gave ground, his movements economical, his mind a quiet lake. He could feel Valerius’s rage, a frantic, chaotic energy that beat against his senses. It was a crude instrument, powerful but without focus. Kaelen’s own energy was different. It was the planet’s energy, patient, ancient, and implacable. He felt the subtle shifts in the chamber’s magnetic field, the whisper of air currents, the frantic, bio-electric spike that preceded each of his opponent’s attacks.

A feint, a spin, a low sweep. The glaive’s tip caught Kaelen’s thigh, shearing through fabric and flesh. The pain was a starburst of pure fire, a sudden, blinding nova in his consciousness. He grunted, stumbling back, his leg a sudden stranger. Blood, shockingly dark against the pale sand, welled and traced a path down his shin.

Valerius laughed, a sound like grinding gears. “The little god bleeds! See how his divine ichor stains the dust, just like any common cur’s.”

The courtiers remained silent, statues carved from shadow. Their stillness was its own form of pressure. Kaelen pressed a hand to the wound, his mind fighting the white-hot fog of pain. He had to end this. Valerius’s stamina was artificial, relentless. Kaelen’s was finite.

He closed his eyes for a fraction of a second, shutting out the glinting armor, the sneering face. He listened instead. Not with his ears, but with his skin, with the marrow of his bones. He heard the whine of the glaive, the thumping of Valerius’s augmented heart, the frantic scrabble of his thoughts—a chaotic broadcast of pride and contempt. And beneath it all, the planet’s song. The slow, deep, geologic bass note. He drew on it, a silent invocation to the only power he had ever trusted.

When he opened his eyes, the world had sharpened. The shimmering heat haze seemed to part for him. He saw the almost imperceptible tremor in Valerius’s left hand, the fractional delay as the neural interface processed his next savage command.

Valerius came again, charging for the final, theatrical kill. The glaive rose high, a falling star of manufactured hatred, aimed to split Kaelen from collarbone to sternum.

Kaelen did not retreat. He moved forward, into the attack, his wounded leg a searing anchor. The world slowed to a crawl. The motes of dust hung suspended in the light. He could see the reflection of his own grim face in the polished arc of the descending blade.

His falx did not rise to block. It dropped. He twisted his body, his motion a fluid paradox of agony and grace. As the whining glaive screamed past his ear, close enough to feel the electric heat on his skin, Kaelen’s falx swept up from below. The silent, shimmering edge met the articulated armor at Valerius’s wrist.

There was no sound of impact. Only a soft, final *hiss*.

The energized glaive, its connection to its power source severed, died with a descending whine. Valerius’s armored hand, detached at the wrist, fell to the floor with a hollow clatter. The conduits within it sparked and writhed for a moment, like dying silver worms, before falling dark.

Valerius froze, his final, killing lunge arrested. He stared, uncomprehending, at the stump of his arm, then at the severed hand lying on the sand-dusted mosaic. A look of pure, animal shock replaced the sadistic glee on his face. The duel was over.

Kaelen stood, breathing heavily, the pain in his leg a roaring fire. He did not press the advantage. He simply watched as the truth of his defeat settled upon his enemy. The silence that flooded the chamber was immense, heavier than the throne, older than the suns. It was the silence of a verdict rendered, a future decided not with a shout, but with a whisper of shearing energy in the suffocating, eternal dust.
